Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation2: A technical hurdle is preventing the mentee from advancing on the current project.
Story: I sat at my desk, the unopened browser tab for the Nintendo Switch still glaring at me from the corner of my screen. My son’s hopeful eyes from this morning replayed in my mind—he’d been counting down the days, reminding me of my promise. But the price tag made my stomach twist; with bills piling up, I wasn’t sure if I could justify the expense. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder: “Project update due.” I was stuck on a technical issue, and my mentor had always encouraged me to reach out early if I hit a wall. But I hesitated, not wanting to seem incapable or distracted. I could almost hear my mentor’s voice, urging me to be proactive, to communicate. Yet, every time I started to draft the message, guilt crept in—shouldn’t I be focusing on my family’s needs first? The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding my attention, each with its own set of expectations. I stared at the screen, torn, unable to move forward in either direction.
